In the following two chapter, we will introduce the first differentiation rules and derivatives of the so-called ""elementary function"", which are the building blocks for creating new functions using addition, multiplication, forming quotations and compositions of these functions. We will learn how using these differentiation rules taking the derivative of a complex function term can be reduced to taking the derivatives of these elementary functions. We will treat the ""Chain Rule"" separately, although it would belong in this context. I have included in the list of elementary derivatives the exponential functions, which in our approach will be introduced in Chapter 6, but it is here where they belong.

You need to spend a great deal of time and effort on learning to applying these rules correctly, please practice, practice, practice, do twice or even three times as many exercises as assigned! 574491,7346635,Chap 4.3 Maxima and Minima,"

In this section we first introduce the notions of relative and absolute extrema of a function. We will see that if the function is defined on a closed and bounded interval then it will attain both its absolute maximum and absolute minimum on this interval. In addition, we will see that the extrema of a function can be easily located if we consider its derivative. Fermat's Theorem gives us a very powerful clue: If the function f has an extremum at the point c, then either its derivative is zero at this point or its derivative does not exist at this point. We will call those points of the domain of f critical numbers of f, since they are the points where the function could have an extremum.
